topic.title: Packet Sequence Number Monitoring

body.p: The overhead monitor extracts the packet sequence number from its programmed location for each channel for which it is enabled. When the packet sequence number is located and extracted, it is compared against the expected value for the channel which is the value extracted from the previous packet plus one, with a wraparound from 0xffffffff back to 0x00000000. If the packet sequence number extracted from the packet does not match the expected value, an interrupt status bit is asserted and an error counter increments.

The packet monitor provides a reset feature to force the monitor to an expected packet sequence number of all zeros. The packet assembler in the test packet generator includes a similar reset option to force the generator sequence number back to zero for the next generated packet.

The overhead monitor does additional analysis on any errors in the packet sequence numbers to determine the number of packets dropped in the event that there are packets missing from the stream. The number of dropped packets is accumulated in a separate error counter from the expected value mismatch error counter. If the gap in sequence numbers is greater than 256 then an interrupt is asserted and the dropped packet counter does not increment.
